Posts.Content: Hi, Don't worry, there is light at the end of the tunnel even though it may be a long journey to get there. You are halfway there having a sister who cares. I went through my whole cancer journey and my sister didn't even acknowledge the diagnosis. But I'm still here, five years on and grateful for the people around me who did care and enjoying life a stronger person because of it. Good luck, be strong, plenty of hugs and you'll get there.
Posts.Title: My sister. needs postive messages from people who are in the same...

Posts.Content: Hi, How about making a countdown chart for when it’s all over. Mark the days when she should be feeling brighter and maybe plan nice things to do together. There’s nothing more satisfying than crossing the days off and feeling a step close to the end. And also hav8ng something nice t9 look forward to and aim towards.  Good luck x
Posts.Title: Supporting my SIL

Posts.Content: Hi, I also had the choice to make between NHS and Private. I was recommended NHS and chose NHS, no regrets. Good treatment, excellent follow-up. I don't think that would have been anywhere near as good. I was also told the surgeons were the same. Having all the treatment at the same place worked wonders.  Good luck in your decision and your journey!
Posts.Title: Private or NHS care/treatment decision

Posts.Content: Hi, I had invasive lobular, double mast,chemo and radio and 5 years later, I'm still here. Chemo dragged a bit. Had 6 rounds, all the usual side-effects. Radio was easy but lengthy. I take Anastrozole and plan to take it for a further 5 years. I feel as happy as I can be knowing I have listened to advice, done all I can. I am still here for my family and we are due to go on holiday, my first one abroad since my diagnosis in 2012.  Good luck in making your choices.
Posts.Title: Invasive lobular and chemo

Posts.Content: Hi, I had to have blood tests to check if I had gone into the menopause after my surgery, chemo and radio treatment.  It was borderline, no guarantees so I had to have Zoladex injections and then I opted for surgery to remove my ovaries (oophorectomy), to be absolutely sure and then I was able to take Anastrozole. I still get hot flushes and I suffer with the joint pain, but it was all worth it to give myself the best chance of the cancer not returning. Good luck with your journey.
Posts.Title: Too Many Hot Flushes

Posts.Content: Hi, Great idea letting everyone know about the HOPE course. I went on the very first one at York hospital in Jan 2013 and it was fantastic. I gained lots from it. The most important thing to come from it was the other people in the group. We decided as we had gelled so much that we would carry on meeting up once a month for coffee and a chat. We still support one another over 4 years later.  If you get the chance to do one, I thoroughly recommend it.
Posts.Title: HOPE COURSE !

Posts.Content: Hi, I couldn't have tamoxifen as I've had previous blood clotting problems so I went onto Anastrozole as soon as I had had my first mastectomy. Later followed chemo and radiotherapy and a further mastectomy and oophorectomy. In between both mastectomies, I had Zoladex injections to keep ovaries at bay before ooph. Still on Anastrozole but possibly due to change to a different ai as I've now been on Anas for 5 years and I struggle with the side effects. I'm expecting to be on the new ai for another 5 years.  Good luck.
Posts.Title: Injection or removal of ovaries?

Posts.Content: Hi, Just wanted to say, I had the injections first but then went for the oophorectomy. The op was ok although I had it at the same time as my second mastectomy. No real problems afterwards but much less worry of the cancer coming back. Do what feels right for you. Good luck.
Posts.Title: Injection or removal of ovaries?

Posts.Content: Hi, Really sorry to hear about your mum but by the sounds of it she's got a daughter who is switched on and ready to help get her through it. Arm yourself with as much knowledge as possible, I found it really helped me, especially in my appointments.  I was 48 when I was diagnosed with lobular cancer , grade 2 ER +ve, HER2 -ve, 8cm, had right sided mastectomy, 6 rounds of chemo, 15 sessions of radio, elective left sided mastectomy and oophorectomy. I now take Anastrozole, can't have tamoxifen. Did have Zoladex injections before ooph, will be on further medication for a further 5 years. It's been 5years since my original diagnosis and although I still suffer side effects, aches and pains mainly, I'm just glad I'm still here with my family.  You asked about the MRI, I also had this early on, to check if the cancer had spread anywhere else. My biopsies, 8 altogether, although painful at the time were useful in to deciding what to do next. Although my original diagnosis was hugely delayed by the hospital, once they realised their mistake, they left no stone unturned. I was kept fully informed every step of the way and I still have their support when I need it. The role of the breast care nurse is very important when you are on this journey.  My surgery certainly wasn't delayed once we knew what we were dealing with. It would have been straight away following test results in late Dec but we decided to have Christmas first with the boys.  I was in hospital a week after my first surgery, then in and out during chemo which brought its own problems. Radiotherapy wasn't a picnic either! My later two operations were done on the same day, and took a while to recover from. I would say, all in all my treatment lasted a year before just going onto medication. Be prepared for the unplanned. Take advantage of hospital-free days when you can.  Good luck , but remember everyone's journey is different. X
Posts.Title: Mom diagnosed with invasive lobular breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi, I felt exactly the same after my treatment, it's normal. I also attended a Macmillan HOPE course. It was brilliant. Our group still meet up for coffee and support once a month. I would definitely recommend it.  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Falling apart now it's over
